contents: (2) <u>Senators who begin a filibuster want to usually stop a bill from passing</u>. Bills can pass the Senate with a simple majority of 51 votes. However, it takes 60 votes to stop a filibuster and take a vote. Therefore, a filibuster makes a bill much more difficult to pass. Senators do not necessarily have to speak during the length of the filibuster. By invoking the rules of a filibuster, (3) <u>he</u> can change the number of necessary votes to 60.
